title: Data Sources
text:
The data for this project comes from the SCORE Sports Data Repository, specifically their Olympic Swimming History dataset available at https://data.scorenetwork.org/swimming/olympic_swimming_history.html. This dataset contains comprehensive results from Olympic swimming competitions from 1912 to 2020, including 4,359 individual race results.
The original data source is olympics.com, and the dataset was compiled and made available by datasciencedonut on Kaggle. The data includes all athletes who competed in Olympic swimming events, not just medal winners, which makes it ideal for understanding the full spectrum of Olympic-level performance.
Data cleaning involved converting time formats from minutes:seconds.decimal to total seconds for analysis, removing DNS (Did Not Start) and DQ (Disqualified) entries, and filtering out obvious data entry errors or outliers. No observations were removed based on performance criteria - the goal was to include all legitimate competitive times to show the complete picture of Olympic swimming performance.
The dataset includes the following variables:

Location: Hosting city of the Olympics
Year: Year of the Olympics (1912-2020)
Distance: Distance in meters (relays show number of swimmers × distance per swimmer)
Stroke: Type of swimming stroke (Freestyle, Backstroke, Breaststroke, Butterfly, Individual Medley)
Relay: Binary indicator (0 for individual events, 1 for relay events)
Gender: Men or Women
Team: Three-letter country code
Athlete: Name of the athlete
Results: Time in minutes:seconds.decimal format
Rank: Medal placement (1=Gold, 2=Silver, 3=Bronze, 4=No Medal, 0=DNS/DQ)

title: About
text:
My name is Paramanyu Gupta and I’m a sophomore at Independence High School! You can find my work on GitHub and contact me at manish.gupta321@gmail.com.
This project analyzes Olympic swimming performance data from 1912-2020, focusing on various aspects of the data, ranging from swimming speed to global medal distribution. The code and data are available in the GitHub repository.
This project was created as part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp.

title: Olympic Swimming Speed Trends Graph (1912-2020)
text: Have you ever wondered just how much faster Olympic swimmers have become over the decades, and what factors might be behind that incredible progress? To explore this, I’ve analyzed comprehensive Olympic swimming data spanning from 1912 to 2020, allowing me to examine average speed trends and visualize the global distribution of Olympic medals. Through this project, we’ve clearly seen how Olympic swimmers have consistently and substantially increased their average speeds over the last century, a powerful testament to continuous advancements in both technique and technology.
